US Secretary of State spokesperson Nauert said talks are ongoing with Turkey for the release of Pastor Brunson. However, there were also reports citing a US official that nothing has developed on the Pastor Brunson case and who warned of more actions on Turkey if he is not freed. (Newswires)

Turkey will not use US-made goods in the construction sector; according to reports which cited the Environment and Urbanization Ministry. MARKET RECAP

US stocks were higher with all 3 majors in the green as risk sentiment recovers as Turkey and EM jitters subsided. In terms of earnings, Advanced Auto Parts (AAP) surged following a beat on both top and bottom line, as well as announcing a new USD 600mln share repurchase programme. Tapestry (TPR) also soared after a strong report, providing the best day for the name since 2009 thanks to Kate Spade handbag sales beating expectations. Home Depot (HD) were initially higher pre-market following what seemed like a strong earnings report with beats on both EPS & revenue, as well as raising its FY18 EPS forecast. However, as the conference call started HD noted some of the gains were due to favourable weather this quarter, and it also said it expects gross margins to expand by roughly 41 bps, which is slightly lower than the previous guidance, leading the stock to close slightly in the red. Elsewhere, Tesla’s (TLSA) Musk announced he’s working with Silver Lake and Goldman Sachs to take the co. private, and it was also announced TSLA have formed a committee comprised of three independent directors for the evaluation of a potential privatisation. Yum China (YUMC) were higher after China's sovereign wealth fund and China Investment Corp announced they are in favour of taking the co. private and are seeking to do so. In M&A news, Carl Icahn has taken a U-turn with his view on the Express Scripts (ESRX) & Cigna (CI) deal as he stated he no longer wishes to solicit proxy advisory firms to vote against the deal. Elsewhere, California Water (CWT) submitted a revised offer for SJW Group (SJW) to USD 70/shr, a USD 1.25 increase from the previous offer. SPX +0.64% at 2840, NDX +0.60% at 7490, DJI +0.45% at 25300.

The Treasury complex followed its European peers on Tuesday and remained subdued amid a slightly less risk-averse tone as the situation in Turkey appears less threatening than previous days. The yield curve saw some modest bear-flattening for most of the morning US session with 2yr yield higher by c.2bps and 30yr yield by c.1bps. US 10YR T-notes settled 4+ ticks lower at 120-03+.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 14th August 2018: TRY regains some ground; Libya oil production returns to 1mln BPD
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • SNAP-SHOT: Equities higher, Treasuries lower, crude flat, dollar up.
  • REAR-VIEW: Sentiment improves as TRY turns around; Libya’s oil output to rise back above 1mln BPD.
  • AHEAD: APIs after-market // UK CPI; US Retail Sales and Industrial Production; Earnings from CSCO; weekly EIA inventories.

* TURKEY: Risk-sentiment slightly turned around Tuesday on more reassuring comments from Turkish President Erdogan and Turkish Finance Minister who both vowed that the necessary measures regarding the economy are being taken. As an additional measure, the Turkish Central Bank opened their FX Repo auction today to alleviate pressure on the TRY, with the interest rate at 19.25% for TRY (vs. 17.75% Prev.) and 2.00% for USD. Their Repo auction however remained closed. In regards to Pastor Brunson, the US threatened Turkey with further economic pressures if they refuse to release him, while the US Charges d‘Affairs in Turkey visited the US Pastor Brunson and made reiterations for his case to be resolved.

* SPX +0.64% at 2840, NDX +0.60% at 7490, DJI +0.45% at 25300. SECTORS: Energy +0.26%, Materials +0.77%, Industrials +0.66% Cons Discretionary +0.95%, Cons  Staples +0.64%, Healthcare +0.45%, Financials +0.86%, Tech +0.62%, Telecoms +0.72%, Utilities +0.17%.

* EARNINGS: Advanced Auto Parts (AAP) surged following a beat on both top and bottom line, as well as announcing a new USD 600mln share repurchase programme. Tapestry (TPR) also soared after a strong report, providing the best day for the name since 2009 thanks to Kate Spade handbag sales beating expectations. Home Depot (HD) were initially higher pre-market following what seemed like a strong earnings report with beats on both EPS & revenue, as well as raising its FY18 EPS forecast. However, as the conference call started HD noted some of the gains were due to favourable weather this quarter, and it also said it expects gross margins to expand by roughly 41 bps, which is slightly lower than the previous guidance, leading the stock to close slightly in the red.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Tesla’s (TLSA) Musk announced he’s working with Silver Lake and Goldman Sachs to take the co. private, and it was also announced TSLA have formed a committee comprised of three independent directors for the evaluation of a potential privatisation. Yum China (YUMC) were higher after China's sovereign wealth fund and China Investment Corp announced they are in favour of taking the co. private, and are seeking to do so. 

* M&A: Carl Icahn has taken a U-turn with his view on the Express Scripts (ESRX) & Cigna (CI) deal as he stated he no longer wishes to solicit proxy advisory firms to vote against the deal. Elsewhere, California Water (CWT) submitted a revised offer for SJW Group (SJW) to USD 70/shr, a USD 1.25 increase from the previous offer.

* WTI CRUDE FUTURES (U8) SETTLE 16C LOWER AT USD 67.04/BBL; BRENT CRUDE FUTURES (V8) SETTLE 15C LOWER AT USD 72.46/BBL. Crude prices ended the session relatively flat despite an initial rebound from the prior mornings sell off as markets seemed to focus on lower crude supply from Saudi Arabia and Iran. Despite the bullish price action in early trade, reports that Libya’s Sharara oil field, which has a production capacity of 300k BPD, is now producing at a normal rate again, pushing Libya’s overall output back to over 1mln BPD failed to spur any move. However, as the settlement approached both WTI & Brent erased earlier gains to close in negative territory amid broad based USD strength.

Tonight’s API data Crude is expected to show a drawdown of 2.5mln barrels, distillates expecting a build of 1mln barrels and gasoline expected to report a drawdown of 600k barrels.

* US 10YR T-NOTES SETTLE 4+ TICKS LOWER AT 120-03+.

The Treasury complex followed its European peers on Tuesday and remained subdued amid a slightly less risk-averse tone as the situation in Turkey appears less threatening than previous days. The yield curve saw some modest bear-flattening for most of the morning US session with 2yr yield higher by c.2bps and 30yr yield by c.1bps.

* LIRA: It remains too early to call or venture with any real conviction, but the signs/omens appear somewhat better for the ailing TRY. Indeed, the Lira and EM currency counterparts witnessed considerably less volatility on their way to what looks like decent rebounds from recent lows, if not extended recovery gains. Moreover, USDTRY did not retrace too far on the latest admonishments from Turkey’s President Erdogan or comments from his Finance Minister pledging to maintain measures to support the Lira, banks and companies, or the latter’s proclaim that the TRY will continue to revalue. USDTRY continued to fall in afternoon trade despite broad-based USD strength, with the pair hitting lows at 6.3057, while even the ARS got a belated boost from the 500bp emergency rate hike on Monday.

* USD: After some early EU session weakness (in wake of offers around 96.400 that tripped a few stops placed at 96.150), the DXY and broad Dollar have been mainly taking cues from fluctuations elsewhere. The USD benefitted from some strength in late in afternoon which pushed the DXY above 96.700.

* CAD, EUR: The Loonie had briefly reclaimed 1.3100 status on a combination of positive NAFTA comments from US President Trump and broad-based USD strength. The single currency failed to sustain 1.1400+ levels again even though EZ data/surveys were mostly supportive and declined later in the session as the USD appreciated across the board.

* NZD, CHF: The Kiwi and Franc both flat vs the USD around 0.6600 and 0.9900 respectively, with the former deriving some impetus from upbeat NZ Finance Minister comments overnight (flagging upbeat economic fundamentals) and the latter unmoved on Swiss PPI data.

* GBP: The Pound saw some temporary post-UK data upside (4% jobless rate) but could not keep hold of 1.2800 and above vs the USD before retreating further towards 1.2755 on more Brexit warnings about no deal or a disorderly withdrawal from the EU. The pair printed fresh lows towards 1.2700 on the back of late afternoon USD strength, a level which cable has not fallen through since June last year.

* JPY, AUD: Weaker vs the Buck from the off, with USDJPY trading in a 110.60-111.30 range, albeit largely above the big figure, and AUDUSD dropping below yesterday’s circa 1 ½ year lows around 0.7250 following disappointing Chinese data and another official weakening of the CNY from the PBoC (and CNH subsequently touching 6.9000 vs the USD).

subject: Daily FX Wrap: turnaround Tuesday for the Try, EMs and overall risk sentiment?
content:
LIRA

It remains too early to call or venture with any real conviction, but the signs/omens appear somewhat better for the ailing Try. Indeed, the Lira and EM currency counterparts witnessed considerably less volatility on their way to what looks like decent rebounds from recent lows, if not extended recovery gains. Moreover, Usd/Try did not retrace too far on the latest admonishments from Turkey’s President Erdogan or comments from his Finance Minister pledging to maintain measures to support the Lira, banks and companies, or the latter’s proclaim that the Try will continue to revalue. Usd/Try currently around 6.5200 and within 6.4500-6.6000 parameters for the most part, while even the ARS got a belated boost from the 500 bn emergency rate hike on Monday.

USD

After some early EU session weakness (in wake of offers around 96.400 that tripped a few stops placed at 96.150), the DXY and broad Dollar have been mainly taking cues from fluctuations elsewhere, with the former ranging between 96.143 and 96.442. In terms of G10 peers, the Greenback is ending pretty evenly split with the CAD outperforming and EUR lagging.

The Loonie has reclaimed 1.3000 status on a combination of positive NAFTA comments from US President Trump and a decent rebound in oil prices, but the single currency failed to sustain 1.1400+ levels again even though EZ data/surveys were mostly supportive.

NZD/CHF

The Kiwi and Franc both firmer vs the Usd around 0.6600 and 0.9900 respectively, with the former deriving some impetus from upbeat NZ Finance Minister comments overnight (flagging upbeat economic fundamentals) and the latter unmoved on Swiss PPI data, but extending gains relative the Eur as the cross retreated through 1.1300 (which may prompt some SNB audible intervention, if not physical action).

GBP

The Pound saw some temporary post-UK data upside (4% jobless rate), but could not keep hold of 1.2800 and above vs the Usd before retreating further towards 1.2755 lows on more Brexit warnings about no deal or a disorderly withdrawal from the EU.

JPY/AUD

Weaker vs the Buck from the off, with Usd/Jpy hugging the upper end of a 110.60-111.15 range, albeit largely above below the big figure, and Aud/Usd only just holding above yesterday’s circa 1 ½ year lows around 0.7250 following disappointing Chinese data and another official weakening of the Cny from the PBoC (and Cnh subsequently touching 6.9000 vs the Usd).

subject: EU DEBT UPDATE: Gilts edge further beyond Bunds and just above parity
content: Within the confines of summer trading volumes and relatively tight ranges, UK debt is marginally stretching upside parameters and outperformance vs core Eurozone Bunds with a firmer rebound from session lows to 123.44 (+5 ticks vs -23 ticks at one stage). The moderate decoupling and divergence started post-data, but latest Brexit headlines are also Gilt supportive as yet another MP notes rising no deal Brexit risk. Moreover, a prominent bank recently advised buying UK bonds on the prospect of Britain leaving the EU without a formal withdrawal agreement and terms for life after. Technically, nothing in terms of resistance until 124.27 aside from the obvious psychological 124.00 level, while Bunds face several hurdles if they fill a gap between 163.35-41, like 163.50 and Monday’s Eurex high at 163.62.

14th August 2018

Earnings

  • Advance Auto Parts (AAP) Q2 Adj. EPS USD 1.97 vs. Exp. USD 1.86, revenue USD 2.3bln vs. Exp. USD 2.27bln. Reports Q2 SSS up 2.8%. Announces new USD 600mln share repurchase programme. Sees FY18 revenue USD 9.3bln-9.5bln vs. Exp. USD 9.38bln. Names Shepherd as CFO effective August 12th. (Newswires)
  • AXA Equitable (EQH) Q2 EPS USD 0.90 vs. Exp. USD 0.86, revenue USD 2.96bln vs. Exp. USD 3.10bln. The co. announces a USD 500mln share repurchase programme and declares a dividend of USD 0.13/shr. (Newswires)
  • Brinker (EAT) Q4 EPS ex-items USD 1.19 vs. Exp. USD 1.19, revenue USD 0.817bln vs. Exp. USD 0.818bln. Sees FY19 ex-items EPS USD 3.70-3.90 vs. Exp. USD 3.76. Sees FY19 revenue growth 1%-2.25%. Sees FY19 comparable restaurant sales up 0.75%-1.75%. (Newswires)
  • Home Depot Inc (HD) Q2 EPS USD 3.05 vs. Exp. USD 2.84, revenue USD 30.5bln vs. Exp. USD 30.03bln. Raises FY18 EPS view to USD 9.42, consensus USD 9.45. (Newswires)
  • Switch (SWCH) Q2 EPS USD 0.02 vs. Exp. USD 0.04, revenue USD 0.102bln vs. Exp. USD 0.103bln. Cuts FY18 revenue guidance. (Newswires)
  • Tapestry (TPR) Q4 Adj. EPS USD 0.60 vs. Exp. USD 0.57, revenue USD 1.48bln vs. Exp. USD 1.47bln. Sees FY19 EPS USD 2.70-2.80 vs. Exp. USD 2.82. Sees FY19 revenue USD 6.1bln-6.2bln vs. Exp. USD 6.08bln. Anticipates FY19 operating income growth rate exceeding revenue growth rate. Q4 Coach SSS up 2%, Q4 Kate Spade SSS down 3%. (Newswires)
  • Vipshop (VIPS) Q2 Adj. EPS USD 0.13 vs. Exp. USD 0.14, revenue USD 3.1bln vs. Exp. USD 3.08bln. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – Turkish President Erdogan said he will boycott electronic products following the additional tariffs announcement coming from the US, stating the country will stop offering iPhones and will replace them with Korean Samsung (SSNLF) or Turkish-made Vestel. Separately, the tech giant held a meeting back in 2017 with 30 developers to push for app subscriptions. (AP/Business Insider)
  • Coca-Cola (KO) - The beverage behemoth is buying a minority stake in BodyArmour, the sports drink backed by Kobe Bryant, in an attempt to compete against energy drink producer Gatorade, a subsidiary of Pepsi Co. (PEP). (Newswires)
  • JPMorgan (JPM) – The bank will no longer offer investment accounts to foreign retail clients as reported by a spokesperson. (Newswires)  
  • McDonald’s (MCD) – The restaurant chain is to invest USD 6bln by 2020 to modernise restaurants across the US. Franchisers are investing USD 170mln in Georgia in 2018/2019 for the construction and modernisation of 340 restaurants. (Newswires)
  • Microsoft (MSFT) – The tech giant is looking to update Cortana, its struggling digital assistant, to get more customers to use the assistant when not at their computer. (Newswires)  

S&P500

  • Alaska Air (ALK) – Reports July traffic up 7.6%, capacity up 6.8%. (Newswires)
  • Cigna Corp (CI) – Carl Icahn said on Monday that he no longer wishes to solicit proxy advisory firms to vote against the Cigna-Express Scripts (ESRX) deal, a U-turn from his stance last week. (Newswires)
  • Mattel (MAT) – The co. names Adriana Cisneros, CEO of Cisneros Group of Companies, and Roger Lynch, CEO of Pandora (P), to the board of directors. (Newswires)

Net new assets excluding mutual; fund clearing at USD 15.8bln. Core net new assets brought to co. by clients at USD 15.8bln. (Newswires)
  • Williams Companies Inc (WMB) – The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has approved the co.’s Transco natural gas pipeline; setting an operational date in time for 2019/20 winter. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Biogen (BIIB) - UK.'s National Institute for Health and Care Excellence says that the biotech’s muscled disease drug Spinraza is too expensive for healthcare services with a list price of USD 750k for the first-year treatment. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – Senior executive Campbell Brown admitted privately that CEO Mark Zuckerberg ‘doesn’t care about publishers’ and said if they do not cooperate with the co. ‘I'll be holding your hands with your dying business like in a hospice’. Later a spokesperson on CNBC noted those comments were ‘taken out of context’. Separately, the social platform acquired Vidpresso’s team and technology but not the co. itself. Vispresso works closely with TV broadcasters making improving videos performance by making them more interactive.   • Tesla (TSLA) – CEO Elon Musk said he is working with Silver Lake and Goldman Sachs (GS) on his plan to take the automaker private. Silver Lake was not hired by the co. as a financial adviser but is offering support without compensation a source said. The automaker reported to have formed a committee comprised of three independent directors for the evaluation of a potential going private transaction; nonetheless the special committee is yet to receive a formal proposal from CEO Elon Musk. Additionally, some significant investors may not be able to follow the CEO’s plan to take the co. private as they would have to drop their shares which would make it more complicated building a stake in the co. Separately, Saudi Arabia may also face challenges in financing a takeover of the co. as its finances are tight. (Newswires/WSJ)

  • TRY building on recovery post-liquidity measures, up ~4%, although Erdogan remains defiant
  • UK Unemployment rate falls to lowest in over 40 years, but real wage growth stagnates, GBP erased early morning gains and currently flat
  • Looking ahead the highlight is API weekly crude inventories

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed as some of the regional bourses shrugged off the negative lead from Wall St where the S&P 500 and DJIA declined for a 4th consecutive day amid the Turkey-triggered turmoil, although China underperformed as participants digested weaker than expected data. ASX 200 (+0.8%) and Nikkei 225 (+2.1%) were higher with Australia lifted by a broad positive tone across nearly all sectors and as focus shifted back to earnings, while Japan outperformed as exporters coat-tailed on a rebound in USD/JPY. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) underperformed their peers and traded negative amid disappointing data in which Industrial Production, Retail Sales and Fixed Urban Assets all fell short of estimates and the Unemployment Rate also increased. Finally, 10yr JGBs were weaker amid the improved risk appetite in Japan with prices also subdued by the absence of the BoJ’s bond buying program from the market today.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8695 (Prev. 6.8629)

Chinese Industrial Production (Jul) Y/Y 6.0% vs. Exp. 6.3% (Prev. 6.0%). (Newswires)
Chinese Retail Sales (Jul) Y/Y 8.8% vs. Exp. 9.1% (Prev. 9.0%)
Chinese Fixed Assets Investment Ex-Rural YTD (Jul) Y/Y Jul 5.5% vs. Exp. 6.0% (Prev. 6.0%)
Chinese Jobless Rate (Jul) 5.1% (Prev. 4.8%)

EU/UK/US

Lawyer for Pastor Brunson has filed an appeal to release the Pastor from house arrest and lift his travel ban, as according a document. The Turkish foreign minister said a US Consular official is set to visit Pastor Brunson today (Newswires)

Turkish President Erdogan says that they are taking the necessary measures regarding the economy and that it is important they keep a firm political stance. (Newswires)

Turkish Central Bank opened their FX Repo auction, with the interest rate at 19.25% for TRY (vs. 17.75% Prev.) and 2.00% for USD. They did not open their Repo auction (Newswires)

Tory Brexiteers are said to be planning to challenge PM May by publishing their own blueprint favouring a hard Brexit. The paper is due to be published next month and is expected to have the backing of 60 to 80 Conservative MPs. It is understood the paper is to allow a possible Canadian-style free trade agreement, only if the EU backs down on demands over the Irish border. (Times)

UK Average Earnings (Ex-Bonus) Jun 2.7% vs. Exp. 2.7% (Prev. 2.7%, Rev. 2.8%)

UK ILO Unemployment Rate Jun 4.0% vs. Exp. 4.2% (Prev. 4.2%)

EU GDP Flash Estimate YY Q2 2.2% vs. Exp. 2.1% (Prev. 2.1%)

EU GDP Flash Estimate QQ Q2 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.3%)

German ZEW Current Conditions Aug 72.6 vs. Exp. 72.3 (Prev. 72.4)

German ZEW Economic Sentiment Aug -13.7 vs. Exp. -20.7 (Prev. -24.7)

GEOPOLITICAL

White House said National Security Adviser Bolton met with Turkish Ambassador Kilic at the White House in which they discussed Pastor Brunson and US-Turkey relations, while the meeting was said to be at the Turkish ambassador's request. In separate news, there were also reports that the US was said to warn Turkey again regarding Pastor Brunson. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities have started the day firmer (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.2%) however gains have been trimmed as Erdogan continues his defiant tone. The FTSE is the underperforming bourse, weighed on by mining names. This coming in the wake of poor Antofagasta earnings, which were hit by a 16% drop in core earnings, and are close to the foot of the Stoxx 600.

Home Depot Inc (HD) Q2 EPS USD 3.05 vs. Exp. USD 2.84, revenue USD 30.5bln vs. Exp. USD 30.03bln

FIXED INCOME

Gilts have rebounded relatively firmly from new Liffe lows and some volatility in wake of a rather mixed UK jobs and earnings update, with a brief sell-off on the 4% unemployment rate and record level of vacancies reversed on the less upbeat elements like claims, headline pay growth and employment change. The 10 year benchmark is now around 123.31 vs 123.38 at best and the 123.16 base, while Bunds remain nearer the bottom of their 163.11-35 range after mainly better than expected Eurozone releases via prelim national and pan GDP estimates and ZEW indices. Elsewhere, US Treasuries are softer and steeper amidst the overall improvement in risk appetite due to Try/EM respite.

FX

EM - A more concerted Try recovery has filtered through the region and beyond again, with a broad improvement in other ‘risky’ currencies and sentiment overall. The Lira is currently pivoting 6.5000 vs the Usd vs 7.2000+ levels at one stage yesterday, as the CBRT augments its RRR interventions via a hike in financing costs at the latest FX auction, albeit not actually opening the repo for a 2nd day presumably due to no excessive demand for extra funds/liquidity. Elsewhere, the Rand, Rouble and Peso are also paring heavy losses, for the time being at least after similar rebounds in Asian counterparts overnight, bar the Yuan that was undermined buy a raft of sub-consensus Chinese data overnight and yet another higher Usd/Cny midpoint fixing.

CAD/GBP/NZD - The top or better G10 performers as the Loonie extends its rebound vs the Greenback to 1.3100 and even higher at one stage on latest NAFTA news (specifically US President Trump stating that things will be sorted with Canada and Mexico, while Canada’s Finance Minister Morneau believes the framework can be improved to benefit all 3 nations). Cable has been choppy around 1.2800 and UK data with a knee-jerk rise on the lowest jobless rate since 1975, before waning on worse than expected claimant count and mixed average earnings. Elsewhere, the Kiwi is holding up relatively well within a 0.6570-0.6605 range amidst upbeat comments from NZ Finance Minister Robertson, noting strong domestic economic fundamentals and the pluses for exporters from Nzd weakness.

CHF/AUD/JPY/EUR - All flat or weaker vs the Dollar after some volatile price action and data, but with the Franc largely shrugging off Swiss producer and import prices and still meandering between 0.9910-45. However, the Aud continues to trade in line with Chinese counterparts and data amidst the ongoing US trade spat and is back down near Monday’s multi-month low circa 0.7250, while the Jpy has retreated sharply to 111.00 or just under and the single currency continues to face resistance above 1.1400.

DXY - The index remains underpinned above 96.000, but equally toppy around 96.500 with moves largely emanating from basket components and pairings on the back of Try/EM fluctuations. Indeed, the DXY and broad Usd traded down to lows when the Lira was around 6.4000 peaks, but then bounced after the latest speech from Turkish President Erdogan as the Try lost momentum.

COMMODITIES

The oil market is benefitting from the return to a positive risk tone and has erased the previous sessions losses, with both WTI and Brent up ~0.8% on the day, with traders looking ahead to the latest API release with expectations set to show a draw in Crude by 3.27mln, Distillates to build by 0.9mln and Gasoline to draw by 0.8mln.

In the metals scope, Gold is flat whilst copper has fallen for the third day straight and pushed YTD losses to 16% as poor Chinese retail sales data suggests demand could slow from the Asian country. Silver (+0.7%), platinum (+0.9%) and palladium (+0.1%) were all beneficiaries of the improved risk sentiment, however, with all of the precious metals up on the day.

subject: PRIMER: UK Labour Market Data to be released at 09.30BST/04:30EDT
content: On Tuesday the UK will release its most recent labour market data, with market participants looking for justification of the BoE’s hike on August the 8th. Wage growth remains the focus, with Average Earnings (Ex-Bonus) expected at 2.7%. This would mean that wages marginally exceeded headline CPI and developed real income growth for the 5th consecutive month. Coupling this with an unemployment rate forecast to stay at 4.2% in spite of fewer jobs added to the economy than previously (98k vs. 137k Prev.) would support the BoE’s rhetoric of a tightening labour market and may offer a floor to a GBP that has been sliding ever since the BoE’s meeting on August 8th, Brussels permitting, of course.

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling labouring ahead of UK jobs and earnings data
content: Several bearish impulses at play off the Liffe open as UK debt and STIR futures acknowledge a more pronounced recovery in the Lira and other EM currencies, alongside some unwinding of Italian fiscal premium and safe-haven positioning in Eurozone debt markets. However, contacts also note that a few major players are anticipating good news on the domestic front from the latest jobs/earnings report via possible beats on the claimant count and average weekly wage growth. Accordingly, Gilts have traded softer from the off between 123.33-21 vs Monday’s 123.39 settlement, and 3 month contracts are flat to 2 ticks adrift.

Bunds: another erosion off the Eurex open
content: Firmer than forecast German q/q GDP may have contributed to the downside, but the latest decline in core 10 year bonds is mainly on external and peripheral factors. First and foremost, the beleaguered Try has extended its rebound overnight, albeit with official aid in the form of Monday’s CBRT indirect intervention, while Italian BTPs are also on the rebound following pledges by the Populist Government to cut the country’s heavy debt load. Hence, Bunds are on the retreat again after a flattish start vs yesterday’s 163.36 close to a 163.12 early low. Ahead, ZEW’s August survey and more hard data in the form of pan Eurozone growth after the aforementioned German release.

ASIA

Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) underperformed their peers and traded negative amid disappointing data in which Industrial Production, Retail Sales and Fixed Urban Assets all fell short of estimates and the Unemployment Rate also increased. content:

  • Asian equity markets traded mixed as some of the regional bourses shrugged off the negative lead from Wall St. Chinese bourses underperformed their peers amid disappointing Chinese data
  • Tory Brexiteers are said to be planning to challenge PM May by publishing their own blueprint favouring a hard Brexit
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German GDP and ZEW Survey, UK jobs data and API weekly crude inventories

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed as some of the regional bourses shrugged off the negative lead from Wall St where the S&P 500 and DJIA declined for a 4th consecutive day amid the Turkey-triggered turmoil, although China underperformed as participants digested weaker than expected data. ASX 200 (+0.8%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.8%) were higher with Australia lifted by a broad positive tone across nearly all sectors and as focus shifted back to earnings, while Japan outperformed as exporters coat-tailed on a rebound in USD/JPY. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) underperformed their peers and traded negative amid disappointing data in which Industrial Production, Retail Sales and Fixed Urban Assets all fell short of estimates and the Unemployment Rate also increased. Finally, 10yr JGBs were weaker amid the improved risk appetite in Japan with prices also subdued by the absence of the BoJ’s bond buying program from the market today.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8695 (Prev. 6.8629)

Chinese Industrial Production (Jul) Y/Y 6.0% vs. Exp. 6.3% (Prev. 6.0%). (Newswires)
Chinese Retail Sales (Jul) Y/Y 8.8% vs. Exp. 9.1% (Prev. 9.0%)
Chinese Fixed Assets Investment Ex-Rural YTD (Jul) Y/Y Jul 5.5% vs. Exp. 6.0% (Prev. 6.0%)
Chinese Jobless Rate (Jul) 5.1% (Prev. 4.8%)


UK/EU

Tory Brexiteers are said to be planning to challenge PM May by publishing their own blueprint favouring a hard Brexit. The paper is due to be published next month and is expected to have the backing of 60 to 80 Conservative MPs. It is understood the paper is to allow a possible Canadian-style free trade agreement, only if the EU backs down on demands over the Irish border. (Times)

Italy officials stated that any reports which say Finance Minister Tria is resigning are baseless. (Newswires)

Bundesbank’s Wuermeling said ECB has not seen a need for a bank meeting on Turkey risks and suggested not to over dramatize the risk of a Euro area infection. (Newswires)


FX

FX markets have calmed from the prior day’s EM sell-off with the USD index relatively flat above the 96.00 level, while its counterparts struggled for direction in which EUR/USD struggled to hold above 1.1400 and with GBP/USD kept rangebound at the 1.2700 handle. Elsewhere, the improvement in risk-tone helped USD/JPY and JPY-crosses sustain their recovery while commodity-linked currencies also saw mild gains amid the rebound in crude, although upside in AUD was contained by the disappointing Chinese data and softness in CNH after the PBoC continued to weaken the reference rate.


 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were relatively flat with WTI crude futures marginally higher as trade stabilized from the prior day’s volatility in which prices slumped briefly below USD 66/bbl before paring nearly all the losses to reclaim the USD 67/bbl level heading into the settlement. Elsewhere, gold languished and only managed to nurse a miniscule portion of Monday’s USD-induced losses, while copper was indecisive amid similar price action across the complex and the mixed overnight risk tone.  

Escondida copper mine workers union are to extend discussions with the BHP for another day. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

White House said National Security Adviser Bolton met with Turkish Ambassador Kilic at the White House in which they discussed Pastor Brunson and US-Turkey relations, while the meeting was said to be at the Turkish ambassador's request. In separate news, there were also reports that the US was said to warn Turkey again regarding Pastor Brunson. (Newswires)
 

US

Treasury yields rebounded from the 4-week lows seen in recent. The complex edged lower after the Turkish Central Bank announced liquidity release on Monday contributing to easing some global tensions. The yield curve saw some modest bear-steepening as most of the action was concentrated in the long end of the curve where 30yr yields were higher by c.3bps at settlement. 5s30s and 10s30s widened by c.1.5bps, 2s5s narrowed by c.1bps. US 10YR T-notes settled 4 ticks lower at 120-08.

US President Trump stated during public fundraiser that they will straighten it out with Mexico and Canada. Elsewhere, there were also earlier comments from Canada’s Finance Minister Morneau that the NAFTA framework can be improved to benefit all three parties and added they will have more to say about steel trade soon. (Newswires)
